preface.title: Dramatis Personae

para.personname: ANTONIO, a sea captain, friend to Sebastian.
A Sea Captain, friend to Viola.
SIR TOBY BELCH, uncle to Olivia.
Lords, Priests, Sailors, Officers, Musicians, and other Attendants.

preface.para: SCENE A city in Illyria, and the sea-coast near it.

section.title: SCENE I. DUKE ORSINO's palace.
section.para: Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and other Lords; Musicians attending

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: If music be the food of love, play on;
Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting,
The appetite may sicken, and so die.
That strain again! it had a dying fall:
O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,
That breathes upon a bank of violets,
Stealing and giving odour! Enough; no more:
'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
O spirit of love! how quick and fresh art thou,
That, notwithstanding thy capacity
Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,
Of what validity and pitch soe'er,
But falls into abatement and low price,
Even in a minute: so full of shapes is fancy
That it alone is high fantastical.

linegroup.speaker: CURIO
linegroup.line: Will you go hunt, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: What, Curio?

linegroup.speaker: CURIO
linegroup.line: The hart.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have:
O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,
Methought she purged the air of pestilence!
That instant was I turn'd into a hart;
And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,
E'er since pursue me.
How now! what news from her?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: So please my lord, I might not be admitted;
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself, till seven years' heat,
Shall not behold her face at ample view;
But, like a cloistress, she will veiled walk
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine: all this to season
A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh
And lasting in her sad remembrance.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
How will she love, when the rich golden shaft
Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else
That live in her; when liver, brain and heart,
These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and fill'd
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flowers:
Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

section.title: SCENE II. The sea-coast.
section.para: Enter VIOLA, a Captain, and Sailors

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: What country, friends, is this?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: This is Illyria, lady.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elysium.
Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you, sailors?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: True, madam: and, to comfort you with chance,
Assure yourself, after our ship did split,
When you and those poor number saved with you
Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,
Most provident in peril, bind himself,
Courage and hope both teaching him the practise,
To a strong mast that lived upon the sea;
Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back,
I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves
So long as I could see.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: For saying so, there's gold:
Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy speech serves for authority,
The like of him. Know'st thou this country?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Ay, madam, well; for I was bred and born
Not three hours' travel from this very place.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Who governs here?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: What is the name?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Orsino.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Orsino! I have heard my father name him:
He was a bachelor then.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: And so is now, or was so very late;
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then 'twas fresh in murmur,--as, you know,
What great ones do the less will prattle of,--
That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: What's she?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count
That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her
In the protection of his son, her brother,
Who shortly also died: for whose dear love,
They say, she hath abjured the company
And sight of men.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: O that I served that lady
And might not be delivered to the world,
Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,
What my estate is!

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: That were hard to compass;
Because she will admit no kind of suit,
No, not the duke's.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain;
And though that nature with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee
I will believe thou hast a mind that suits
With this thy fair and outward character.
I prithee, and I'll pay thee bounteously,
Conceal me what I am, and be my aid
For such disguise as haply shall become
The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:
Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him:
It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing
And speak to him in many sorts of music
That will allow me very worth his service.
What else may hap to time I will commit;
Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be:
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I thank thee: lead me on.

section.title: SCENE III. OLIVIA'S house.
section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of
her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o'
nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great
exceptions to your ill hours.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, let her except, before excepted.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest
limits of order.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Confine! I'll confine myself no finer than I am:
these clothes are good enough to drink in; and so be
these boots too: an they be not, let them hang
themselves in their own straps.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard
my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish
knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ay, he.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: What's that to the purpose?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats:
he's a very fool and a prodigal.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the
viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages
word for word without book, and hath all the good
gifts of nature.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that
he's a fool, he's a great quarreller: and but that
he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he
hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent
he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors
that say so of him. Who are they?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to
her as long as there is a passage in my throat and
drink in Illyria: he's a coward and a coystrill
that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn
o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench!
Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Sweet Sir Andrew!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Bless you, fair shrew.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: And you too, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: What's that?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: My niece's chambermaid.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: My name is Mary, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Good Mistress Mary Accost,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: You mistake, knight; 'accost' is front her, board
her, woo her, assail her.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this
company. Is that the meaning of 'accost'?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Fare you well, gentlemen.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst
never draw sword again.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never
draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have
fools in hand?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Marry, but you shall have; and here's my hand.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray you, bring
your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's your metaphor?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: It's dry, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can
keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: A dry jest, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Are you full of them?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry,
now I let go your hand, I am barren.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I
see thee so put down?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Never in your life, I think; unless you see canary
put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit
than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a
great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: No question.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An I thought that, I'ld forswear it. I'll ride home
to-morrow, Sir Toby.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: What is 'Pourquoi'? do or not do? I would I had
bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in
fencing, dancing and bear-baiting: O, had I but
followed the arts!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Why, would that have mended my hair?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Excellent; it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I
hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs
and spin it off.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby: your niece
will not be seen; or if she be, it's four to one
she'll none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: She'll none o' the count: she'll not match above
her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I
have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't,
man.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the
strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques
and revels sometimes altogether.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the
degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare
with an old man.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Faith, I can cut a caper.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And I can cut the mutton to't.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong
as any man in Illyria.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Wherefore are these things hid? wherefore have
these gifts a curtain before 'em? are they like to
take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? why dost
thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in
a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not
so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What
dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?
I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy
leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a
flame-coloured stock. Shall we set about some revels?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What shall we do else? were we not born under Taurus?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let me see the
caper; ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!

section.title: SCENE IV. DUKE ORSINO's palace.
section.para: Enter VALENTINE and VIOLA in man's attire

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: If the duke continue these favours towards you,
Cesario, you are like to be much advanced: he hath
known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: You either fear his humour or my negligence, that
you call in question the continuance of his love:
is he inconstant, sir, in his favours?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: No, believe me.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I thank you. Here comes the count.

section.para: Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and Attendants

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Who saw Cesario, ho?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: On your attendance, my lord; here.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Stand you a while aloof, Cesario,
Thou know'st no less but all; I have unclasp'd
To thee the book even of my secret soul:
Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;
Be not denied access, stand at her doors,
And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow
Till thou have audience.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Sure, my noble lord,
If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds
Rather than make unprofited return.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: O, then unfold the passion of my love,
Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:
It shall become thee well to act my woes;
She will attend it better in thy youth
Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I think not so, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Dear lad, believe it;
For they shall yet belie thy happy years,
That say thou art a man: Diana's lip
Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe
Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound,
And all is semblative a woman's part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affair. Some four or five attend him;
All, if you will; for I myself am best
When least in company. Prosper well in this,
And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I'll do my best
To woo your lady:
yet, a barful strife!
Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will
not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in
way of thy excuse: my lady will hang thee for thy absence.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this
world needs to fear no colours.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Make that good.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: He shall see none to fear.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: A good lenten answer: I can tell thee where that
saying was born, of 'I fear no colours.'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Where, good Mistress Mary?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those
that are fools, let them use their talents.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent; or,
to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and,
for turning away, let summer bear it out.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: You are resolute, then?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Not so, neither; but I am resolved on two points.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: That if one break, the other will hold; or, if both
break, your gaskins fall.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Apt, in good faith; very apt. Well, go thy way; if
Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a
piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my
lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Wit, an't be thy will, put me into good fooling!
Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft
prove fools; and I, that am sure I lack thee, may
pass for a wise man: for what says Quinapalus?
'Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit.'
God bless thee, lady!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Take the fool away.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Go to, you're a dry fool; I'll no more of you:
besides, you grow dishonest.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel
will amend: for give the dry fool drink, then is
the fool not dry: bid the dishonest man mend
himself; if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if
he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Any thing
that's mended is but patched: virtue that
transgresses is but patched with sin; and sin that
amends is but patched with virtue. If that this
simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not,
what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but
calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take
away the fool; therefore, I say again, take her away.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Sir, I bade them take away you.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, cucullus non
facit monachum; that's as much to say as I wear not
motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to
prove you a fool.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Can you do it?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Dexterously, good madonna.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Make your proof.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I must catechise you for it, madonna: good my mouse
of virtue, answer me.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I'll bide your proof.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Good fool, for my brother's death.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother's
soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? doth he not mend?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him:
infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the
better fool.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the
better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be
sworn that I am no fox; but he will not pass his
word for two pence that you are no fool.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: How say you to that, Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a
barren rascal: I saw him put down the other day
with an ordinary fool that has no more brain
than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard
already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to
him, he is gagged. I protest, I take these wise men,
that crow so at these set kind of fools, no better
than the fools' zanies.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste
with a distempered appetite. To be generous,
guiltless and of free disposition, is to take those
things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets:
there is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do
nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet
man, though he do nothing but reprove.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou
speakest well of fools!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much
desires to speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: From the Count Orsino, is it?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: I know not, madam: 'tis a fair young man, and well attended.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Who of my people hold him in delay?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks nothing but
madman: fie on him!
Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit from the count, I
am sick, or not at home; what you will, to dismiss it.
Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and
people dislike it.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest
son should be a fool; whose skull Jove cram with
brains! for,--here he comes,--one of thy kin has a
most weak pia mater.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: By mine honour, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: A gentleman.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: A gentleman! what gentleman?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: 'Tis a gentle man here--a plague o' these
pickle-herring! How now, sot!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Good Sir Toby!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Ay, marry, what is he?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not: give
me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What's a drunken man like, fool?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Like a drowned man, a fool and a mad man: one
draught above heat makes him a fool; the second mads
him; and a third drowns him.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my
coz; for he's in the third degree of drink, he's
drowned: go, look after him.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: He is but mad yet, madonna; and the fool shall look
to the madman.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with
you. I told him you were sick; he takes on him to
understand so much, and therefore comes to speak
with you. I told him you were asleep; he seems to
have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore
comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him,
lady? he's fortified against any denial.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Has been told so; and he says, he'll stand at your
door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to
a bench, but he'll speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What kind o' man is he?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Why, of mankind.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What manner of man?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Of very ill manner; he'll speak with you, will you or no.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Of what personage and years is he?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for
a boy; as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a
cooling when 'tis almost an apple: 'tis with him
in standing water, between boy and man. He is very
well-favoured and he speaks very shrewishly; one
would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face.
We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Speak to me; I shall answer for her.
Your will?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty,--I
pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house,
for I never saw her: I would be loath to cast away
my speech, for besides that it is excellently well
penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good
beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very
comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Whence came you, sir?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I can say little more than I have studied, and that
question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me
modest assurance if you be the lady of the house,
that I may proceed in my speech.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Are you a comedian?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs
of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you
the lady of the house?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp
yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours
to reserve. But this is from my commission: I will
on with my speech in your praise, and then show you
the heart of my message.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: It is the more like to be feigned: I pray you,
keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates,
and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you
than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone; if
you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of
moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies your way.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: No, good swabber; I am to hull here a little
longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet
lady. Tell me your mind: I am a messenger.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when
the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of
war, no taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my
hand; my words are as fun of peace as matter.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Yet you began rudely. What are you? what would you?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I
learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I
would, are as secret as maidenhead; to your ears,
divinity, to any other's, profanation.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity.
Now, sir, what is your text?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Most sweet lady,--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it.
Where lies your text?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: In Orsino's bosom.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: In his bosom! In what chapter of his bosom?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Good madam, let me see your face.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate
with my face? You are now out of your text: but
we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.
Look you, sir, such a one I was this present: is't
not well done?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Excellently done, if God did all.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: 'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind and weather.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white
Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on:
Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,
If you will lead these graces to the grave
And leave the world no copy.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted; I will give
out divers schedules of my beauty: it shall be
inventoried, and every particle and utensil
labelled to my will: as, item, two lips,
indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to
them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were
you sent hither to praise me?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I see you what you are, you are too proud;
But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
My lord and master loves you: O, such love
Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd
The nonpareil of beauty!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: How does he love me?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: With adorations, fertile tears,
With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Your lord does know my mind; I cannot love him:
Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,
Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth;
In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant;
And in dimension and the shape of nature
A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him;
He might have took his answer long ago.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: If I did love you in my master's flame,
With such a suffering, such a deadly life,
In your denial I would find no sense;
I would not understand it.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Why, what would you?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Make me a willow cabin at your gate,
And call upon my soul within the house;
Write loyal cantons of contemned love
And sing them loud even in the dead of night;
Halloo your name to the reverberate hills
And make the babbling gossip of the air
Cry out 'Olivia!' O, You should not rest
Between the elements of air and earth,
But you should pity me!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: You might do much.
What is your parentage?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:
I am a gentleman.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Get you to your lord;
I cannot love him: let him send no more;
Unless, perchance, you come to me again,
To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well:
I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse:
My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
Love make his heart of flint that you shall love;
And let your fervor, like my master's, be
Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: 'What is your parentage?'
'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:
I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art;
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit,
Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast:
soft, soft!
Unless the master were the man. How now!
Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
Methinks I feel this youth's perfections
With an invisible and subtle stealth
To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.
What ho, Malvolio!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Here, madam, at your service.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Run after that same peevish messenger,
The county's man: he left this ring behind him,
Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it.
Desire him not to flatter with his lord,
Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him:
If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,
I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Madam, I will.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I do I know not what, and fear to find
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe;
What is decreed must be, and be this so.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Will you stay no longer? nor will you not that I go with you?

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over
me: the malignancy of my fate might perhaps
distemper yours; therefore I shall crave of you your
leave that I may bear my evils alone: it were a bad
recompense for your love, to lay any of them on you.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: No, sooth, sir: my determinate voyage is mere
extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a
touch of modesty, that you will not extort from me
what I am willing to keep in; therefore it charges
me in manners the rather to express myself. You
must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian,
which I called Roderigo. My father was that
Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard
of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both
born in an hour: if the heavens had been pleased,
would we had so ended! but you, sir, altered that;
for some hour before you took me from the breach of
the sea was my sister drowned.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Alas the day!

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled
me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but,
though I could not with such estimable wonder
overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly
publish her; she bore a mind that envy could not but
call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt
water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be
your servant.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: If you will not undo what you have done, that is,
kill him whom you have recovered, desire it not.
Fare ye well at once: my bosom is full of kindness,
and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that
upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell
tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
I have many enemies in Orsino's court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there.
But, come what may, I do adore thee so,
That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I have since
arrived but hither.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: She returns this ring to you, sir: you might have
saved me my pains, to have taken it away yourself.
She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord
into a desperate assurance she will none of him:
and one thing more, that you be never so hardy to
come again in his affairs, unless it be to report
your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her; and her
will is, it should be so returned: if it be worth
stooping for, there it lies in your eye; if not, be
it his that finds it.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I left no ring with her: what means this lady?
Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her!
She made good view of me; indeed, so much,
That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,
For she did speak in starts distractedly.
She loves me, sure; the cunning of her passion
Invites me in this churlish messenger.
None of my lord's ring! why, he sent her none.
I am the man: if it be so, as 'tis,
Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
Disguise, I see, thou art a wickedness,
Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.
How easy is it for the proper-false
In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!
Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!
For such as we are made of, such we be.
How will this fadge? my master loves her dearly;
And I, poor monster, fond as much on him;
And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.
What will become of this? As I am man,
My state is desperate for my master's love;
As I am woman,--now alas the day!--
What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!
O time! thou must untangle this, not I;
It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

section.title: SCENE III. OLIVIA's house.
section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Approach, Sir Andrew: not to be abed after
midnight is to be up betimes; and 'diluculo
surgere,' thou know'st,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Nay, my troth, I know not: but I know, to be up
late is to be up late.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: A false conclusion: I hate it as an unfilled can.
To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is
early: so that to go to bed after midnight is to go
to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the
four elements?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Faith, so they say; but I think it rather consists
of eating and drinking.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Thou'rt a scholar; let us therefore eat and drink.
Marian, I say! a stoup of wine!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: How now, my hearts! did you never see the picture
of 'we three'?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I
had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg,
and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In
sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last
night, when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the
Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus: 'twas
very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy
leman: hadst it?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I did impeticos thy gratillity; for Malvolio's nose
is no whipstock: my lady has a white hand, and the
Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Excellent! why, this is the best fooling, when all
is done. Now, a song.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come on; there is sixpence for you: let's have a song.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: There's a testril of me too: if one knight give a--

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: A love-song, a love-song.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Ay, ay: I care not for good life.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?
O, stay and hear; your true love's coming,
That can sing both high and low:
Trip no further, pretty sweeting;
Journeys end in lovers meeting,
Every wise man's son doth know.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Excellent good, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Good, good.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: What is love? 'tis not hereafter;
Present mirth hath present laughter;
What's to come is still unsure:
In delay there lies no plenty;
Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,
Youth's a stuff will not endure.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: A contagious breath.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.
But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? shall we
rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three
souls out of one weaver? shall we do that?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An you love me, let's do't: I am dog at a catch.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: By'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Most certain. Let our catch be, 'Thou knave.'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'Hold thy peace, thou knave,' knight? I shall be
constrained in't to call thee knave, knight.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to
call me knave. Begin, fool: it begins 'Hold thy peace.'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Good, i' faith. Come, begin.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady
have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him
turn you out of doors, never trust me.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's
a Peg-a-Ramsey, and 'Three merry men be we.' Am not
I consanguineous? am I not of her blood?
Tillyvally. Lady!
'There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do
I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it
more natural.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Sings 'O, the twelfth day of December,'--

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: For the love o' God, peace!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: My masters, are you mad? or what are you? Have ye
no wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like
tinkers at this time of night? Do ye make an
alehouse of my lady's house, that ye squeak out your
coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse
of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor
time in you?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me
tell you, that, though she harbours you as her
kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders. If
you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you
are welcome to the house; if not, an it would please
you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid
you farewell.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: 'Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.'

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Nay, good Sir Toby.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'His eyes do show his days are almost done.'

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Is't even so?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: 'But I will never die.'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Sir Toby, there you lie.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: This is much credit to you.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: 'Shall I bid him go?'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'What an if you do?'

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: 'Shall I bid him go, and spare not?'

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'O no, no, no, no, you dare not.'

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Out o' tune, sir: ye lie. Art any more than a
steward? Dost thou think, because thou art
virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the
mouth too.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with
crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favour at any
thing more than contempt, you would not give means
for this uncivil rule: she shall know of it, by this hand.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Go shake your ears.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's
a-hungry, to challenge him the field, and then to
break promise with him and make a fool of him.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Do't, knight: I'll write thee a challenge: or I'll
deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight: since the
youth of the count's was today with thy lady, she is
much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me
alone with him: if I do not gull him into a
nayword, and make him a common recreation, do not
think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed:
I know I can do it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Possess us, possess us; tell us something of him.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: O, if I thought that I'ld beat him like a dog!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What, for being a puritan? thy exquisite reason,
dear knight?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I have no exquisite reason for't, but I have reason
good enough.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: The devil a puritan that he is, or any thing
constantly, but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass,
that cons state without book and utters it by great
swarths: the best persuaded of himself, so
crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is
his grounds of faith that all that look on him love
him; and on that vice in him will my revenge find
notable cause to work.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What wilt thou do?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of
love; wherein, by the colour of his beard, the shape
of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure
of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find
himself most feelingly personated. I can write very
like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we
can hardly make distinction of our hands.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Excellent! I smell a device.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I have't in my nose too.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop,
that they come from my niece, and that she's in
love with him.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that colour.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: And your horse now would make him an ass.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Ass, I doubt not.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: O, 'twill be admirable!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Sport royal, I warrant you: I know my physic will
work with him. I will plant you two, and let the
fool make a third, where he shall find the letter:
observe his construction of it. For this night, to
bed, and dream on the event. Farewell.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Good night, Penthesilea.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Before me, she's a good wench.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: She's a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me:
what o' that?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I was adored once too.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Let's to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for
more money.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Send for money, knight: if thou hast her not i'
the end, call me cut.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come, come, I'll go burn some sack; 'tis too late
to go to bed now: come, knight; come, knight.

section.title: SCENE IV. DUKE ORSINO's palace.
section.para: Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Give me some music. Now, good morrow, friends.
Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,
That old and antique song we heard last night:
Methought it did relieve my passion much,
More than light airs and recollected terms
Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:
Come, but one verse.

linegroup.speaker: CURIO
linegroup.line: He is not here, so please your lordship that should sing it.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Who was it?

linegroup.speaker: CURIO
linegroup.line: Feste, the jester, my lord; a fool that the lady
Olivia's father took much delight in. He is about the house.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Seek him out, and play the tune the while.
Come hither, boy: if ever thou shalt love,
In the sweet pangs of it remember me;
For such as I am all true lovers are,
Unstaid and skittish in all motions else,
Save in the constant image of the creature
That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: It gives a very echo to the seat
Where Love is throned.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Thou dost speak masterly:
My life upon't, young though thou art, thine eye
Hath stay'd upon some favour that it loves:
Hath it not, boy?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: A little, by your favour.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: What kind of woman is't?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Of your complexion.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: About your years, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Too old by heaven: let still the woman take
An elder than herself: so wears she to him,
So sways she level in her husband's heart:
For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,
Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,
More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,
Than women's are.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I think it well, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Then let thy love be younger than thyself,
Or thy affection cannot hold the bent;
For women are as roses, whose fair flower
Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And so they are: alas, that they are so;
To die, even when they to perfection grow!

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.
Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;
The spinsters and the knitters in the sun
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones
Do use to chant it: it is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love,
Like the old age.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Are you ready, sir?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Ay; prithee, sing.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Come away, come away, death,
And in sad cypress let me be laid;
Fly away, fly away breath;
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
O, prepare it!
My part of death, no one so true
Did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet
On my black coffin let there be strown;
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown:
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
Lay me, O, where
Sad true lover never find my grave,
To weep there!

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: There's for thy pains.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No pains, sir: I take pleasure in singing, sir.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: I'll pay thy pleasure then.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Give me now leave to leave thee.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Now, the melancholy god protect thee; and the
tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for
thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such
constancy put to sea, that their business might be
every thing and their intent every where; for that's
it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Let all the rest give place.
Once more, Cesario,
Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty:
Tell her, my love, more noble than the world,
Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;
The parts that fortune hath bestow'd upon her,
Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;
But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems
That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: But if she cannot love you, sir?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: I cannot be so answer'd.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Sooth, but you must.
Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,
Hath for your love a great a pang of heart
As you have for Olivia: you cannot love her;
You tell her so; must she not then be answer'd?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: There is no woman's sides
Can bide the beating of so strong a passion
As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart
So big, to hold so much; they lack retention
Alas, their love may be call'd appetite,
No motion of the liver, but the palate,
That suffer surfeit, cloyment and revolt;
But mine is all as hungry as the sea,
And can digest as much: make no compare
Between that love a woman can bear me
And that I owe Olivia.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Ay, but I know--

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: What dost thou know?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Too well what love women to men may owe:
In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
My father had a daughter loved a man,
As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,
I should your lordship.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: And what's her history?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,
But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,
Feed on her damask cheek: she pined in thought,
And with a green and yellow melancholy
She sat like patience on a monument,
Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?
We men may say more, swear more: but indeed
Our shows are more than will; for still we prove
Much in our vows, but little in our love.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I am all the daughters of my father's house,
And all the brothers too: and yet I know not.
Sir, shall I to this lady?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Ay, that's the theme.
To her in haste; give her this jewel; say,
My love can give no place, bide no denay.

section.title: SCENE V. OLIVIA's garden.
section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Nay, I'll come: if I lose a scruple of this sport,
let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly
rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: I would exult, man: you know, he brought me out o'
favour with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To anger him we'll have the bear again; and we will
fool him black and blue: shall we not, Sir Andrew?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Here comes the little villain.
How now, my metal of India!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Get ye all three into the box-tree: Malvolio's
coming down this walk: he has been yonder i' the
sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half
hour: observe him, for the love of mockery; for I
know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of
him. Close, in the name of jesting! Lie thou there,
for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Tis but fortune; all is fortune. Maria once told
me she did affect me: and I have heard herself come
thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one
of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more
exalted respect than any one else that follows her.
What should I think on't?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Here's an overweening rogue!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock
of him: how he jets under his advanced plumes!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Peace, I say.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: To be Count Malvolio!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Ah, rogue!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Pistol him, pistol him.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Peace, peace!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: There is example for't; the lady of the Strachy
married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Fie on him, Jezebel!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: O, peace! now he's deeply in: look how
imagination blows him.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Having been three months married to her, sitting in
my state,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: O, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet
gown; having come from a day-bed, where I have left
Olivia sleeping,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Fire and brimstone!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: O, peace, peace!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: And then to have the humour of state; and after a
demure travel of regard, telling them I know my
place as I would they should do theirs, to for my
kinsman Toby,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Bolts and shackles!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: O peace, peace, peace! now, now.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make
out for him: I frown the while; and perchance wind
up watch, or play with my--some rich jewel. Toby
approaches; courtesies there to me,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Shall this fellow live?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar
smile with an austere regard of control,--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Saying, 'Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on
your niece give me this prerogative of speech,'--

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What, what?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'You must amend your drunkenness.'

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Out, scab!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with
a foolish knight,'--

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: That's me, I warrant you.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'One Sir Andrew,'--

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I knew 'twas I; for many do call me fool.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: What employment have we here?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: O, peace! and the spirit of humour intimate reading
aloud to him!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: By my life, this is my lady's hand these be her
very C's, her U's and her T's and thus makes she her
great P's. It is, in contempt of question, her hand.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Her C's, her U's and her T's: why that?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Reads 'To the unknown beloved, this, and my good
wishes:'--her very phrases! By your leave, wax.
Soft! and the impressure her Lucrece, with which she
uses to seal: 'tis my lady. To whom should this be?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: This wins him, liver and all.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Jove knows I love: But who?
Lips, do not move;
No man must know.
'No man must know.' What follows? the numbers
altered! 'No man must know:' if this should be
thee, Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Marry, hang thee, brock!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I may command where I adore;
But silence, like a Lucrece knife,
With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore:
M, O, A, I, doth sway my life.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: A fustian riddle!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Excellent wench, say I.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'M, O, A, I, doth sway my life.' Nay, but first, let
me see, let me see, let me see.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: What dish o' poison has she dressed him!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And with what wing the staniel cheques at it!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'I may command where I adore.' Why, she may command
me: I serve her; she is my lady. Why, this is
evident to any formal capacity; there is no
obstruction in this: and the end,--what should
that alphabetical position portend? If I could make
that resemble something in me,--Softly! M, O, A,

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: O, ay, make up that: he is now at a cold scent.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Sowter will cry upon't for all this, though it be as
rank as a fox.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: M,--Malvolio; M,--why, that begins my name.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Did not I say he would work it out? the cur is
excellent at faults.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: M,--but then there is no consonancy in the sequel;
that suffers under probation A should follow but O does.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: And O shall end, I hope.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Ay, or I'll cudgel him, and make him cry O!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: And then I comes behind.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see
more detraction at your heels than fortunes before
you.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: M, O, A, I; this simulation is not as the former: and
yet, to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for
every one of these letters are in my name. Soft!
here follows prose.
'If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I
am above thee; but be not afraid of greatness: some
are born great, some achieve greatness, and some
have greatness thrust upon 'em. Thy Fates open
their hands; let thy blood and spirit embrace them;
and, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be,
cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be
opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants; let
thy tongue tang arguments of state; put thyself into
the trick of singularity: she thus advises thee
that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy
yellow stockings, and wished to see thee ever
cross-gartered: I say, remember. Go to, thou art
made, if thou desirest to be so; if not, let me see
thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and
not worthy to touch Fortune's fingers. Farewell.
She that would alter services with thee,
THE FORTUNATE-UNHAPPY.'
Daylight and champaign discovers not more: this is
open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors,
I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross
acquaintance, I will be point-devise the very man.
I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade
me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady
loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of
late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered;
and in this she manifests herself to my love, and
with a kind of injunction drives me to these habits
of her liking. I thank my stars I am happy. I will
be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and
cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting
on. Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yet a
postscript.
'Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou
entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling;
thy smiles become thee well; therefore in my
presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.'
Jove, I thank thee: I will smile; I will do
everything that thou wilt have me.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension
of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I could marry this wench for this device.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: So could I too.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Nor I neither.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Or o' mine either?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Shall I play my freedom at traytrip, and become thy
bond-slave?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I' faith, or I either?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream, that when
the image of it leaves him he must run mad.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Nay, but say true; does it work upon him?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Like aqua-vitae with a midwife.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark
his first approach before my lady: he will come to
her in yellow stockings, and 'tis a colour she
abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests;
and he will smile upon her, which will now be so
unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a
melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him
into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow
me.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I'll make one too.

section.title: SCENE I. OLIVIA's garden.
section.para: Enter VIOLA, and Clown with a tabour

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Save thee, friend, and thy music: dost thou live by
thy tabour?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No, sir, I live by the church.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Art thou a churchman?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No such matter, sir: I do live by the church; for
I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by
the church.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: So thou mayst say, the king lies by a beggar, if a
beggar dwell near him; or, the church stands by thy
tabour, if thy tabour stand by the church.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is
but a cheveril glove to a good wit: how quickly the
wrong side may be turned outward!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely with
words may quickly make them wanton.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I would, therefore, my sister had had no name, sir.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Why, man?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Why, sir, her name's a word; and to dally with that
word might make my sister wanton. But indeed words
are very rascals since bonds disgraced them.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Thy reason, man?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words; and
words are grown so false, I am loath to prove
reason with them.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Not so, sir, I do care for something; but in my
conscience, sir, I do not care for you: if that be
to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly: she
will keep no fool, sir, till she be married; and
fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to
herrings; the husband's the bigger: I am indeed not
her fool, but her corrupter of words.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun,
it shines every where. I would be sorry, sir, but
the fool should be as oft with your master as with
my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Nay, an thou pass upon me, I'll no more with thee.
Hold, there's expenses for thee.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick for
one;
though I would not have it grow on my chin. Is thy
lady within?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring
a Cressida to this Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I understand you, sir; 'tis well begged.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but
a beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is
within, sir. I will construe to them whence you
come; who you are and what you would are out of my
welkin, I might say 'element,' but the word is over-worn.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool;
And to do that well craves a kind of wit:
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time,
And, like the haggard, cheque at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practise
As full of labour as a wise man's art
For folly that he wisely shows is fit;
But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.

section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Save you, gentleman.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And you, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I hope, sir, you are; and I am yours.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Will you encounter the house? my niece is desirous
you should enter, if your trade be to her.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I am bound to your niece, sir; I mean, she is the
list of my voyage.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Taste your legs, sir; put them to motion.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I
understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we
are prevented.
Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain
odours on you!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: That youth's a rare courtier: 'Rain odours;' well.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My matter hath no voice, to your own most pregnant
and vouchsafed ear.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Odours,' 'pregnant' and 'vouchsafed:' I'll get 'em
all three all ready.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
linegroup.para: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA
linegroup.line: Give me your hand, sir.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What is your name?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world
Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment:
You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:
Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: For him, I think not on him: for his thoughts,
Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd with me!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalf.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, by your leave, I pray you,
I bade you never speak again of him:
But, would you undertake another suit,
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Dear lady,--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you: so did I abuse
Myself, my servant and, I fear me, you:
Under your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you, in a shameful cunning,
Which you knew none of yours: what might you think?
Have you not set mine honour at the stake
And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
Enough is shown: a cypress, not a bosom,
Hideth my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I pity you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: That's a degree to love.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof,
That very oft we pity enemies.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Why, then, methinks 'tis time to smile again.
O, world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the lion than the wolf!
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you:
And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your were is alike to reap a proper man:
There lies your way, due west.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Then westward-ho! Grace and good disposition
Attend your ladyship!
You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Stay:
I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: That you do think you are not what you are.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: If I think so, I think the same of you.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I would you were as I would have you be!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid: love's night is noon.
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honour, truth and every thing,
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,
But rather reason thus with reason fetter,
Love sought is good, but given unsought better.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: By innocence I swear, and by my youth
I have one heart, one bosom and one truth,
And that no woman has; nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam: never more
Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

section.title: SCENE II. OLIVIA's house.
section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: No, faith, I'll not stay a jot longer.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Marry, I saw your niece do more favours to the
count's serving-man than ever she bestowed upon me;
I saw't i' the orchard.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Did she see thee the while, old boy? tell me that.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: As plain as I see you now.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of
judgment and reason.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And they have been grand-jury-men since before Noah
was a sailor.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: She did show favour to the youth in your sight only
to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valour, to
put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
You should then have accosted her; and with some
excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should
have banged the youth into dumbness. This was
