looked for at your hand, and this was balked: the
double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash
off, and you are now sailed into the north of my
lady's opinion; where you will hang like an icicle
on a Dutchman's beard, unless you do redeem it by
some laudable attempt either of valour or policy.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An't be any way, it must be with valour; for policy
I hate: I had as lief be a Brownist as a
politician.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of
valour. Challenge me the count's youth to fight
with him; hurt him in eleven places: my niece shall
take note of it; and assure thyself, there is no
love-broker in the world can more prevail in man's
commendation with woman than report of valour.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Go, write it in a martial hand; be curst and brief;
it is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and fun
of invention: taunt him with the licence of ink:
if thou thou'st him some thrice, it shall not be
amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of
paper, although the sheet were big enough for the
bed of Ware in England, set 'em down: go, about it.
Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou
write with a goose-pen, no matter: about it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Where shall I find you?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: We'll call thee at the cubiculo: go.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand
strong, or so.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: We shall have a rare letter from him: but you'll
not deliver't?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Never trust me, then; and by all means stir on the
youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes
cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were
opened, and you find so much blood in his liver as
will clog the foot of a flea, I'll eat the rest of
the anatomy.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no
great presage of cruelty.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Look, where the youngest wren of nine comes.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself
into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is
turned heathen, a very renegado; for there is no
Christian, that means to be saved by believing
rightly, can ever believe such impossible passages
of grossness. He's in yellow stockings.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: And cross-gartered?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Most villanously; like a pedant that keeps a school
i' the church. I have dogged him, like his
murderer. He does obey every point of the letter
that I dropped to betray him: he does smile his
face into more lines than is in the new map with the
augmentation of the Indies: you have not seen such
a thing as 'tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things
at him. I know my lady will strike him: if she do,
he'll smile and take't for a great favour.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I would not by my will have troubled you;
But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,
I will no further chide you.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: I could not stay behind you: my desire,
More sharp than filed steel, did spur me forth;
And not all love to see you, though so much
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,
Being skilless in these parts; which to a stranger,
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable: my willing love,
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: My kind Antonio,
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks; and ever oft good turns
Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay:
But, were my worth as is my conscience firm,
You should find better dealing. What's to do?
Shall we go see the reliques of this town?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: To-morrow, sir: best first go see your lodging.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I am not weary, and 'tis long to night:
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Would you'ld pardon me;
I do not without danger walk these streets:
Once, in a sea-fight, 'gainst the count his galleys
I did some service; of such note indeed,
That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answer'd.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Belike you slew great number of his people.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answer'd in repaying
What we took from them; which, for traffic's sake,
Most of our city did: only myself stood out;
For which, if I be lapsed in this place,
I shall pay dear.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Do not then walk too open.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse.
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge: I will bespeak our diet,
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town: there shall you have me.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Why I your purse?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase; and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I'll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: To the Elephant.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I do remember.

section.title: SCENE IV. OLIVIA's garden.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I have sent after him: he says he'll come;
How shall I feast him? what bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg'd or borrow'd.
I speak too loud.
Where is Malvolio? he is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes:
Where is Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: He's coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He
is, sure, possessed, madam.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Why, what's the matter? does he rave?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: No. madam, he does nothing but smile: your
ladyship were best to have some guard about you, if
he come; for, sure, the man is tainted in's wits.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Go call him hither.
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.
How now, Malvolio!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Smilest thou?
I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sad, lady! I could be sad: this does make some
obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering; but
what of that? if it please the eye of one, it is
with me as the very true sonnet is, 'Please one, and
please all.'

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Why, how dost thou, man? what is the matter with thee?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It
did come to his hands, and commands shall be
executed: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: To bed! ay, sweet-heart, and I'll come to thee.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so and kiss
thy hand so oft?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: How do you, Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: At your request! yes; nightingales answer daws.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Be not afraid of greatness:' 'twas well writ.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Some are born great,'--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Ha!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Some achieve greatness,'--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What sayest thou?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'And some have greatness thrust upon them.'

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Heaven restore thee!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Remember who commended thy yellow stockings,'--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Thy yellow stockings!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'And wished to see thee cross-gartered.'

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Cross-gartered!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'Go to thou art made, if thou desirest to be so;'--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Am I made?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: 'If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Why, this is very midsummer madness.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's is
returned: I could hardly entreat him back: he
attends your ladyship's pleasure.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I'll come to him.
Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's
my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special
care of him: I would not have him miscarry for the
half of my dowry.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: O, ho! do you come near me now? no worse man than
Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly with
the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may
appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that
in the letter. 'Cast thy humble slough,' says she;
'be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants;
let thy tongue tang with arguments of state; put
thyself into the trick of singularity;' and
consequently sets down the manner how; as, a sad
face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the
habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have
limed her; but it is Jove's doing, and Jove make me
thankful! And when she went away now, 'Let this
fellow be looked to:' fellow! not Malvolio, nor
after my degree, but fellow. Why, every thing
adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no
scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous
or unsafe circumstance--What can be said? Nothing
that can be can come between me and the full
prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the
doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

section.para: Re-enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all
the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion
himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir?
how is't with you, man?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy my private: go
off.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! did not
I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a
care of him.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Ah, ha! does she so?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Go to, go to; peace, peace; we must deal gently
with him: let me alone. How do you, Malvolio? how
is't with you? What, man! defy the devil:
consider, he's an enemy to mankind.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Do you know what you say?

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes
it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Carry his water to the wise woman.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow morning, if I
live. My lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: How now, mistress!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: O Lord!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not the way: do
you not see you move him? let me alone with him.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: No way but gentleness; gently, gently: the fiend is
rough, and will not be roughly used.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, how now, my bawcock! how dost thou, chuck?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Ay, Biddy, come with me. What, man! 'tis not for
gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan: hang
him, foul collier!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: My prayers, minx!

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle shallow
things: I am not of your element: you shall know
more hereafter.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Is't possible?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: If this were played upon a stage now, I could
condemn it as an improbable fiction.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: The house will be the quieter.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound. My
niece is already in the belief that he's mad: we
may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance,
till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt
us to have mercy on him: at which time we will
bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a
finder of madmen. But see, but see.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: More matter for a May morning.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Here's the challenge, read it: warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Is't so saucy?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Ay, is't, I warrant him: do but read.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Give me.
'Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.'

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Good, and valiant.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Reads 'Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind,
why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for't.'

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: A good note; that keeps you from the blow of the law.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Reads 'Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my
sight she uses thee kindly: but thou liest in thy
throat; that is not the matter I challenge thee for.'

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense--less.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Reads 'I will waylay thee going home; where if it
be thy chance to kill me,'--

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Good.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Reads 'Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain.'

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law: good.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Reads 'Fare thee well; and God have mercy upon
one of our souls! He may have mercy upon mine; but
my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy
friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK.
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot:
I'll give't him.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: You may have very fit occasion for't: he is now in
some commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Go, Sir Andrew: scout me for him at the corner the
orchard like a bum-baily: so soon as ever thou seest
him, draw; and, as thou drawest swear horrible; for
it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a
swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood
more approbation than ever proof itself would have
earned him. Away!

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Now will not I deliver his letter: for the behavior
of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good
capacity and breeding; his employment between his
lord and my niece confirms no less: therefore this
letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no
terror in the youth: he will find it comes from a
clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by
word of mouth; set upon Aguecheek a notable report
of valour; and drive the gentleman, as I know his
youth will aptly receive it, into a most hideous
opinion of his rage, skill, fury and impetuosity.
This will so fright them both that they will kill
one another by the look, like cockatrices.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Here he comes with your niece: give them way till
he take leave, and presently after him.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message
for a challenge.

section.para: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honour too unchary out:
There's something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mocks reproof.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: With the same 'havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture;
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honour saved may upon asking give?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Nothing but this; your true love for my master.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: How with mine honour may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I will acquit you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Well, come again to-morrow: fare thee well:
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

section.para: Re-enter SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Gentleman, God save thee.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And you, sir.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: That defence thou hast, betake thee to't: of what
nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know
not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as
the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end:
dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for
thy assailant is quick, skilful and deadly.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any quarrel
to me: my remembrance is very free and clear from
any image of offence done to any man.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: You'll find it otherwise, I assure you: therefore,
if you hold your life at any price, betake you to
your guard; for your opposite hath in him what
youth, strength, skill and wrath can furnish man withal.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I pray you, sir, what is he?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on
carpet consideration; but he is a devil in private
brawl: souls and bodies hath he divorced three; and
his incensement at this moment is so implacable,
that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death
and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word; give't or take't.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I will return again into the house and desire some
conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard
of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on
others, to taste their valour: belike this is a man
of that quirk.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a
very competent injury: therefore, get you on and
give him his desire. Back you shall not to the
house, unless you undertake that with me which with
as much safety you might answer him: therefore, on,
or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle you
must, that's certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me
this courteous office, as to know of the knight what
my offence to him is: it is something of my
negligence, nothing of my purpose.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this
gentleman till my return.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a
mortal arbitrement; but nothing of the circumstance more.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by
his form, as you are like to find him in the proof
of his valour. He is, indeed, sir, the most skilful,
bloody and fatal opposite that you could possibly
have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk
towards him? I will make your peace with him if I
can.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I shall be much bound to you for't: I am one that
had rather go with sir priest than sir knight: I
care not who knows so much of my mettle.

section.para: Re-enter SIR TOBY BELCH, with SIR ANDREW

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Why, man, he's a very devil; I have not seen such a
firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard and
all, and he gives me the stuck in with such a mortal
motion, that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he
pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they
step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Ay, but he will not now be pacified: Fabian can
scarce hold him yonder.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Plague on't, an I thought he had been valiant and so
cunning in fence, I'ld have seen him damned ere I'ld
have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip,
and I'll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I'll make the motion: stand here, make a good show
on't: this shall end without the perdition of souls.
Marry, I'll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
I have his horse to take up the quarrel:
I have persuaded him the youth's a devil.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants and
looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To VIOLA There's no remedy, sir; he will fight
with you for's oath sake: marry, he hath better
bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now
scarce to be worth talking of: therefore draw, for
the supportance of his vow; he protests he will not hurt you.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Aside Pray God defend me! A little thing would
make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Give ground, if you see him furious.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman
will, for his honour's sake, have one bout with you;
he cannot by the duello avoid it: but he has
promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he
will not hurt you. Come on; to't.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Pray God, he keep his oath!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I do assure you, 'tis against my will.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: You, sir! why, what are you?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: O good Sir Toby, hold! here come the officers.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I'll be with you anon.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Marry, will I, sir; and, for that I promised you,
I'll be as good as my word: he will bear you easily
and reins well.

linegroup.speaker: First Officer
linegroup.line: This is the man; do thy office.

linegroup.speaker: Second Officer
linegroup.line: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: You do mistake me, sir.

linegroup.speaker: First Officer
linegroup.line: No, sir, no jot; I know your favour well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away: he knows I know him well.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: I must obey.
This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed;
But be of comfort.

linegroup.speaker: Second Officer
linegroup.line: Come, sir, away.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: I must entreat of you some of that money.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show'd me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something: my having is not much;
I'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there's half my coffer.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Will you deny me now?
Is't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: I know of none;
Nor know I you by voice or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: O heavens themselves!

linegroup.speaker: Second Officer
linegroup.line: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

linegroup.speaker: First Officer
linegroup.line: What's that to us? The time goes by: away!

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: But O how vile an idol proves this god
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind;
None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind:
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourish'd by the devil.

linegroup.speaker: First Officer
linegroup.line: The man grows mad: away with him! Come, come, sir.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Lead me on.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself: so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian: we'll
whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: He named Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favour was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than
a hare: his dishonesty appears in leaving his
friend here in necessity and denying him; and for
his cowardship, ask Fabian.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Do; cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: An I do not,--

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Come, let's see the event.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.

section.title: SCENE I. Before OLIVIA's house.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow:
Let me be clear of thee.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not know you; nor
I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come
speak with her; nor your name is not Master Cesario;
nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that is so is so.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else: Thou
know'st not me.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Vent my folly! he has heard that word of some
great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my
folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world,
will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy
strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my
lady: shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me: There's
money for thee: if you tarry longer, I shall give
worse payment.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men
that give fools money get themselves a good
report--after fourteen years' purchase.

section.para: Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY BELCH, and FABIAN

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Now, sir, have I met you again? there's for you.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Why, there's for thee, and there, and there. Are all
the people mad?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger o'er the house.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: This will I tell my lady straight: I would not be
in some of your coats for two pence.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come on, sir; hold.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: Nay, let him alone: I'll go another way to work
with him; I'll have an action of battery against
him, if there be any law in Illyria: though I
struck him first, yet it's no matter for that.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Let go thy hand.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young
soldier, put up your iron: you are well fleshed; come on.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I will be free from thee. What wouldst thou now? If
thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two
of this malapert blood from you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Hold, Toby; on thy life I charge thee, hold!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Madam!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne'er were preach'd! out of my sight!
Be not offended, dear Cesario.
Rudesby, be gone!
linegroup.para: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN
linegroup.line: I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and thou unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botch'd up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this: thou shalt not choose but go:
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: What relish is in this? how runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream:
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Nay, come, I prithee; would thou'ldst be ruled by me!

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Madam, I will.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, say so, and so be!

section.title: SCENE II. OLIVIA's house.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard;
make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate: do
it quickly; I'll call Sir Toby the whilst.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself
in't; and I would I were the first that ever
dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to
become the function well, nor lean enough to be
thought a good student; but to be said an honest man
and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a
careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.

section.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for, as the old hermit of
Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily
said to a niece of King Gorboduc, 'That that is is;'
so I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson; for,
what is 'that' but 'that,' and 'is' but 'is'?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To him, Sir Topas.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: What, ho, I say! peace in this prison!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: The knave counterfeits well; a good knave.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Within Who calls there?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio
the lunatic.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest thou this man!
talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Well said, Master Parson.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged: good Sir
Topas, do not think I am mad: they have laid me
here in hideous darkness.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most
modest terms; for I am one of those gentle ones
that will use the devil himself with courtesy:
sayest thou that house is dark?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: As hell, Sir Topas.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Why it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes,
and the clearstores toward the south north are as
lustrous as ebony; and yet complainest thou of
obstruction?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I am not mad, Sir Topas: I say to you, this house is dark.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Madman, thou errest: I say, there is no darkness
but ignorance; in which thou art more puzzled than
the Egyptians in their fog.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though
ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say, there
was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you
are: make the trial of it in any constant question.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wild fowl?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness:
thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will
allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock, lest
thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Nay, I am for all waters.

linegroup.speaker: MARIA
linegroup.line: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and
gown: he sees thee not.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how
thou findest him: I would we were well rid of this
knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I
would he were, for I am now so far in offence with
my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this
sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.

section.para: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,
Tell me how thy lady does.'

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'My lady is unkind, perdy.'

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'Alas, why is she so?'

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool, I say!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: 'She loves another'--Who calls, ha?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my
hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink and paper:
as I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to
thee for't.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Master Malvolio?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Ay, good fool.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I
am as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: But as well? then you are mad indeed, if you be no
better in your wits than a fool.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: They have here propertied me; keep me in darkness,
send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to
face me out of my wits.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Advise you what you say; the minister is here.
Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore!
endeavour thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain
bibble babble.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Sir Topas!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Maintain no words with him, good fellow. Who, I,
sir? not I, sir. God be wi' you, good Sir Topas.
Merry, amen. I will, sir, I will.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am
shent for speaking to you.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper: I
tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Well-a-day that you were, sir

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper and
light; and convey what I will set down to my lady:
it shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing
of letter did.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I will help you to't. But tell me true, are you
not mad indeed? or do you but counterfeit?

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Believe me, I am not; I tell thee true.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I see his
brains. I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Fool, I'll requite it in the highest degree: I
prithee, be gone.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I'll be with you again,
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who, with dagger of lath,
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! to the devil:
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad;
Adieu, good man devil.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: This is the air; that is the glorious sun;
This pearl she gave me, I do feel't and see't;
And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet 'tis not madness. Where's Antonio, then?
I could not find him at the Elephant:
Yet there he was; and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service;
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad
Or else the lady's mad; yet, if 'twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs and their dispatch
With such a smooth, discreet and stable bearing
As I perceive she does: there's something in't
That is deceiveable. But here the lady comes.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,
Now go with me and with this holy man
Into the chantry by: there, before him,
And underneath that consecrated roof,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith;
That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
May live at peace. He shall conceal it
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keep
According to my birth. What do you say?

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I'll follow this good man, and go with you;
And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine,
That they may fairly note this act of mine!

section.title: SCENE I. Before OLIVIA's house.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Any thing.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Do not desire to see this letter.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: This is, to give a dog, and in recompense desire my
dog again.

section.para: Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and Lords

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Ay, sir; we are some of her trappings.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: I know thee well; how dost thou, my good fellow?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse
for my friends.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Just the contrary; the better for thy friends.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No, sir, the worse.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: How can that be?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me;
now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass: so that by
my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself,
and by my friends, I am abused: so that,
conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives
make your two affirmatives why then, the worse for
my friends and the better for my foes.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Why, this is excellent.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: By my troth, sir, no; though it please you to be
one of my friends.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there's gold.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would
you could make it another.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: O, you give me ill counsel.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once,
and let your flesh and blood obey it.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a
double-dealer: there's another.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play; and the old
saying is, the third pays for all: the triplex,
sir, is a good tripping measure; or the bells of
Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind; one, two, three.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw:
if you will let your lady know I am here to speak
with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake
my bounty further.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come
again. I go, sir; but I would not have you to think
that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness:
but, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I
will awake it anon.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: That face of his I do remember well;
Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmear'd
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war:
A bawbling vessel was he captain of,
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable;
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
That very envy and the tongue of loss
Cried fame and honour on him. What's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: First Officer
linegroup.line: Orsino, this is that Antonio
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy;
And this is he that did the Tiger board,
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg:
Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In private brabble did we apprehend him.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side;
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me:
I know not what 'twas but distraction.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Notable pirate! thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,
Hast made thine enemies?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Orsino, noble sir,
Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me:
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,
Though I confess, on base and ground enough,
Orsino's enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingrateful boy there by your side,
From the rude sea's enraged and foamy mouth
Did I redeem; a wreck past hope he was:
His life I gave him and did thereto add
My love, without retention or restraint,
All his in dedication; for his sake
Did I expose myself, pure for his love,
Into the danger of this adverse town;
Drew to defend him when he was beset:
Where being apprehended, his false cunning,
Not meaning to partake with me in danger,
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twenty years removed thing
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse,
Which I had recommended to his use
Not half an hour before.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: How can this be?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: When came he to this town?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: To-day, my lord; and for three months before,
No interim, not a minute's vacancy,
Both day and night did we keep company.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Here comes the countess: now heaven walks on earth.
But for thee, fellow; fellow, thy words are madness:
Three months this youth hath tended upon me;
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Madam!

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Gracious Olivia,--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord,--

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Still so cruel?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Still so constant, lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: What, to perverseness? you uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull'st offerings hath breathed out
That e'er devotion tender'd! What shall I do?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,
Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love?--a savage jealousy
That sometimes savours nobly. But hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favour,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still;
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master's spite.
Come, boy, with me; my thoughts are ripe in mischief:
I'll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven's heart within a dove.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And I, most jocund, apt and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Where goes Cesario?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Ay me, detested! how am I beguiled!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Hast thou forgot thyself? is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Come, away!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Husband!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Ay, husband: can he that deny?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Her husband, sirrah!

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: No, my lord, not I.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety:
Fear not, Cesario; take thy fortunes up;
Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear'st.
O, welcome, father!
Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,
Here to unfold, though lately we intended
To keep in darkness what occasion now
Reveals before 'tis ripe, what thou dost know
Hath newly pass'd between this youth and me.

linegroup.speaker: Priest
linegroup.line: A contract of eternal bond of love,
Confirm'd by mutual joinder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lips,
Strengthen'd by interchangement of your rings;
And all the ceremony of this compact
Seal'd in my function, by my testimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell'd but two hours.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: O thou dissembling cub! what wilt thou be
When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow,
That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet
Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My lord, I do protest--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: O, do not swear!
Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently
to Sir Toby.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: What's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby
a bloody coxcomb too: for the love of God, your
help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: The count's gentleman, one Cesario: we took him for
a coward, but he's the very devil incardinate.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: My gentleman, Cesario?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: 'Od's lifelings, here he is! You broke my head for
nothing; and that that I did, I was set on to do't
by Sir Toby.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you:
You drew your sword upon me without cause;
But I bespoke you fair, and hurt you not.

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me: I
think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
linegroup.para: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and Clown
linegroup.line: Here comes Sir Toby halting; you shall hear more:
but if he had not been in drink, he would have
tickled you othergates than he did.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: How now, gentleman! how is't with you?

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: That's all one: has hurt me, and there's the end
on't. Sot, didst see Dick surgeon, sot?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: O, he's drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone; his eyes
were set at eight i' the morning.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Then he's a rogue, and a passy measures panyn: I
hate a drunken rogue.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?

linegroup.speaker: SIR ANDREW
linegroup.line: I'll help you, Sir Toby, because well be dressed together.

linegroup.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
linegroup.line: Will you help? an ass-head and a coxcomb and a
knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be look'd to.

section.para: Exeunt Clown, FABIAN, SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman:
But, had it been the brother of my blood,
I must have done no less with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that
I do perceive it hath offended you:
Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows
We made each other but so late ago.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A natural perspective, that is and is not!

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
How have the hours rack'd and tortured me,
Since I have lost thee!

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: Sebastian are you?

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Fear'st thou that, Antonio?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: How have you made division of yourself?
An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Most wonderful!

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature,
Of here and every where. I had a sister,
Whom the blind waves and surges have devour'd.
Of charity, what kin are you to me?
What countryman? what name? what parentage?

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father;
Such a Sebastian was my brother too,
So went he suited to his watery tomb:
If spirits can assume both form and suit
You come to fright us.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: A spirit I am indeed;
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
I should my tears let fall upon your cheek,
And say 'Thrice-welcome, drowned Viola!'

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: My father had a mole upon his brow.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: And so had mine.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had number'd thirteen years.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: O, that record is lively in my soul!
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurp'd attire,
Do not embrace me till each circumstance
Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
That I am Viola: which to confirm,
I'll bring you to a captain in this town,
Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
I was preserved to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.

linegroup.speaker: SEBASTIAN
linegroup.line: To OLIVIA So comes it, lady, you have been mistook:
But nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid;
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived,
You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Be not amazed; right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,
I shall have share in this most happy wreck.
Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: And all those sayings will I overswear;
And those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Give me thy hand;
And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.

linegroup.speaker: VIOLA
linegroup.line: The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid's garments: he upon some action
Is now in durance, at Malvolio's suit,
A gentleman, and follower of my lady's.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither:
And yet, alas, now I remember me,
They say, poor gentleman, he's much distract.
linegroup.para: Re-enter Clown with a letter, and FABIAN
linegroup.line: A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish'd his.
How does he, sirrah?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the staves's end as
well as a man in his case may do: has here writ a
letter to you; I should have given't you to-day
morning, but as a madman's epistles are no gospels,
so it skills not much when they are delivered.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Open't, and read it.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers
the madman.
'By the Lord, madam,'--

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: How now! art thou mad?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: No, madam, I do but read madness: an your ladyship
will have it as it ought to be, you must allow Vox.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: So I do, madonna; but to read his right wits is to
read thus: therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Read it you, sirrah.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Reads 'By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the
world shall know it: though you have put me into
darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over
me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as
your ladyship. I have your own letter that induced
me to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt
not but to do myself much right, or you much shame.
Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little
unthought of and speak out of my injury.
THE MADLY-USED MALVOLIO.'

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Did he write this?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Ay, madam.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: This savours not much of distraction.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: See him deliver'd, Fabian; bring him hither.
My lord so please you, these things further
thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown the alliance on't, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
Your master quits you; and for your service done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you call'd me master for so long,
Here is my hand: you shall from this time be
Your master's mistress.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: A sister! you are she.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Is this the madman?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio!

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Have I, Malvolio? no.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is your hand:
Write from it, if you can, in hand or phrase;
Or say 'tis not your seal, nor your invention:
You can say none of this: well, grant it then
And tell me, in the modesty of honour,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favour,
Bade me come smiling and cross-garter'd to you,
To put on yellow stockings and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And, acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffer'd me to be imprison'd,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e'er invention play'd on? tell me why.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though, I confess, much like the character
But out of question 'tis Maria's hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad; then camest in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presupposed
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content:
This practise hath most shrewdly pass'd upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

linegroup.speaker: FABIAN
linegroup.line: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wonder'd at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceived against him: Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby's great importance;
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow'd,
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge;
If that the injuries be justly weigh'd
That have on both sides pass'd.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: Why, 'some are born great, some achieve greatness,
and some have greatness thrown upon them.' I was
one, sir, in this interlude; one Sir Topas, sir; but
that's all one. 'By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.'
But do you remember? 'Madam, why laugh you at such
a barren rascal? an you smile not, he's gagged:'
and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

linegroup.speaker: MALVOLIO
linegroup.line: I'll be revenged on the whole pack of you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVIA
linegroup.line: He hath been most notoriously abused.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE ORSINO
linegroup.line: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace:
He hath not told us of the captain yet:
When that is known and golden time convents,
A solemn combination shall be made
Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario, come;
For so you shall be, while you are a man;
But when in other habits you are seen,
Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man's estate,
With hey, ho, &c.
'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came, alas! to wive,
With hey, ho, &c.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey, ho, &c.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, &c.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey, ho, &c.
But that's all one, our play is done,
And we'll strive to please you every day.
